a.name: a
a.summary: The `<a>` HTML element (or anchor element), with its `href` attribute, creates a hyperlink to web pages, files, email addresses, locations in the same page, or anything else a URL can address.

download.name: download
download.summary: Causes the browser to treat the linked URL as a download. Can be used with or without a value.

href.name: href
href.summary: The URL that the hyperlink points to. Links are not restricted to HTTP-based URLs — they can use any URL scheme supported by browsers.

hreflang.name: hreflang
hreflang.summary: Hints at the human language of the linked URL. No built-in functionality. Allowed values are the same as the global `lang` attribute.

ping.name: ping
ping.summary: A space-separated list of URLs. When the link is followed, the browser will send POST requests with the body `PING` to the URLs. Typically for tracking.

referrerpolicy.name: referrerpolicy
referrerpolicy.summary: How much of the referrer to send when following the link.

rel.name: rel
rel.summary: The relationship of the linked URL as space-separated link types.

target.name: target
target.summary: Where to display the linked URL, as the name for a browsing context (a tab, window, or iframe). The following keywords have special meanings for where to load the URL.

type.name: type
type.summary: Hints at the linked URL's format with a MIME type. No built-in functionality.

abbr.name: abbr
abbr.summary: The `<abbr>` HTML element represents an abbreviation or acronym; the optional title attribute can provide an expansion or description for the abbreviation. If present, `title` must contain this full description and nothing else.

acronym.name: acronym
acronym.summary: The `<acronym>` HTML element allows authors to clearly indicate a sequence of characters that compose an acronym or abbreviation for a word.

address.name: address
address.summary: The `<address>` HTML element indicates that the enclosed HTML provides contact information for a person or people, or for an organization.

applet.name: applet
applet.summary: The obsolete HTML Applet Element (`<applet>`) embeds a Java applet into the document; this element has been deprecated in favor of object.

align.name: align
align.summary: This attribute is used to position the applet on the page relative to content that might flow around it. The HTML 4.01 specification defines values of `bottom`, `left`, `middle`, `right`, and `top`, whereas Microsoft and Netscape also might support `absbottom`, `absmiddle`, `baseline`, `center`, and `texttop`.

alt.name: alt
alt.summary: This attribute causes a descriptive text alternate to be displayed on browsers that do not support Java. Page designers should also remember that content enclosed within the `<applet>` element may also be rendered as alternative text.

archive.name: archive
archive.summary: This attribute refers to an archived or compressed version of the applet and its associated class files, which might help reduce download time.

code.name: code
code.summary: This attribute specifies the URL of the applet's class file to be loaded and executed. Applet filenames are identified by a .class filename extension. The URL specified by code might be relative to the `codebase` attribute.

codebase.name: codebase
codebase.summary: This attribute gives the absolute or relative URL of the directory where applets' .class files referenced by the code attribute are stored.

datafld.name: datafld
datafld.summary: This attribute, supported by Internet Explorer 4 and higher, specifies the column name from the data source object that supplies the bound data. This attribute might be used to specify the various param elements passed to the Java applet.

datasrc.name: datasrc
datasrc.summary: Like `datafld`, this attribute is used for data binding under Internet Explorer 4. It indicates the id of the data source object that supplies the data that is bound to the param elements associated with the applet.

height.name: height
height.summary: This attribute specifies the height, in pixels, that the applet needs.

hspace.name: hspace
hspace.summary: This attribute specifies additional horizontal space, in pixels, to be reserved on either side of the applet.

mayscript.name: mayscript
mayscript.summary: In the Netscape implementation, this attribute allows access to an applet by programs in a scripting language embedded in the document.

name.name: name
name.summary: This attribute assigns a name to the applet so that it can be identified by other resources; particularly scripts.

object.name: object
object.summary: This attribute specifies the URL of a serialized representation of an applet.

src.name: src
src.summary: As defined for Internet Explorer 4 and higher, this attribute specifies a URL for an associated file for the applet. The meaning and use is unclear and not part of the HTML standard.

vspace.name: vspace
vspace.summary: This attribute specifies additional vertical space, in pixels, to be reserved above and below the applet.

width.name: width
width.summary: This attribute specifies in pixels the width that the applet needs.

area.name: area
area.summary: The `<area>` HTML element defines an area inside an image map that has predefined clickable areas. An image map allows geometric areas on an image to be associated with Hyperlink.

alt.name: alt
alt.summary: A text string alternative to display on browsers that do not display images.

coords.name: coords
coords.summary: The `coords` attribute details the coordinates of the `shape` attribute in size, shape, and placement of an `<area>`.

download.name: download
download.summary: This attribute, if present, indicates that the author intends the hyperlink to be used for downloading a resource.

href.name: href
href.summary: The hyperlink target for the area.

hreflang.name: hreflang
hreflang.summary: Indicates the language of the linked resource. Allowed values are defined by RFC 5646 "Tags for Identifying Languages (also known as BCP 47)".

ping.name: ping
ping.summary: Contains a space-separated list of URLs to which, when the hyperlink is followed, POST requests with the body `PING` will be sent by the browser (in the background).

referrerpolicy.name: referrerpolicy
referrerpolicy.summary: A string indicating which referrer to use when fetching the resource.

rel.name: rel
rel.summary: For anchors containing the href attribute, this attribute specifies the relationship of the target object to the link object.

shape.name: shape
shape.summary: The shape of the associated hot spot. The specifications for HTML defines the values `rect`, which defines a rectangular region; `circle`, which defines a circular region; `poly`, which defines a polygon; and `default`, which indicates the entire region beyond any defined shapes.

target.name: target
target.summary: A keyword or author-defined name of the browsing context to display the linked resource.

article.name: article
article.summary: The `<article>` HTML element represents a self-contained composition in a document, page, application, or site, which is intended to be independently distributable or reusable (e.g., in syndication). Examples include: a forum post, a magazine or newspaper article, or a blog entry, a product card, a user-submitted comment, an interactive widget or gadget, or any other independent item of content.

aside.name: aside
aside.summary: The `<aside>` HTML element represents a portion of a document whose content is only indirectly related to the document's main content. Asides are frequently presented as sidebars or call-out boxes.

audio.name: audio
audio.summary: The `<audio>` HTML element is used to embed sound content in documents. It may contain one or more audio sources, represented using the `src` attribute or the source element: the browser will choose the most suitable one. It can also be the destination for streamed media, using a MediaStream.

autoplay.name: autoplay
autoplay.summary: A Boolean attribute: if specified, the audio will automatically begin playback as soon as it can do so, without waiting for the entire audio file to finish downloading.

controls.name: controls
controls.summary: If this attribute is present, the browser will offer controls to allow the user to control audio playback, including volume, seeking, and pause/resume playback.

crossorigin.name: crossorigin
crossorigin.summary: This enumerated attribute indicates whether to use CORS to fetch the related audio file. CORS-enabled resources can be reused in the canvas element without being tainted. The allowed values are.

disableremoteplayback.name: disableremoteplayback
disableremoteplayback.summary: A Boolean attribute used to disable the capability of remote playback in devices that are attached using wired (HDMI, DVI, etc.) and wireless technologies (Miracast, Chromecast, DLNA, AirPlay, etc). See this proposed specification for more information.

loop.name: loop
loop.summary: A Boolean attribute: if specified, the audio player will automatically seek back to the start upon reaching the end of the audio.

muted.name: muted
muted.summary: A Boolean attribute that indicates whether the audio will be initially silenced. Its default value is `false`.

preload.name: preload
preload.summary: This enumerated attribute is intended to provide a hint to the browser about what the author thinks will lead to the best user experience

src.name: src
src.summary: The URL of the audio to embed. This is subject to HTTP access controls. This is optional; you may instead use the source element within the audio block to specify the audio to embed.

b.name: b
b.summary: The `<b>` HTML element is used to draw the reader's attention to the element's contents, which are not otherwise granted special importance. This was formerly known as the Boldface element, and most browsers still draw the text in boldface. However, you should not use `<b>` for styling text; instead, you should use the CSS font-weight property to create boldface text, or the strong element to indicate that text is of special importance.

base.name: base
base.summary: The `<base>` HTML element specifies the base URL to use for all relative URLs in a document. There can be only one `<base>` element in a document.

href.name: href
href.summary: The base URL to be used throughout the document for relative URLs. Absolute and relative URLs are allowed.

target.name: target
target.summary: A keyword or author-defined name of the default browsing context to show the results of navigation from a, area, or form elements without explicit `target` attributes. The following keywords have special meanings.

basefont.name: basefont
basefont.summary: The `<basefont>` HTML element is deprecated. It sets a default font face, size, and color for the other elements which are descended from its parent element. With this set, the font's size can then be varied relative to the base size using the font element.

color.name: color
color.summary: This attribute sets the text color using either a named color or a color specified in the hexadecimal #RRGGBB format.

face.name: face
face.summary: This attribute contains a list of one or more font names. The document text in the default style is rendered in the first font face that the client's browser supports. If no font listed is installed on the local system, the browser typically defaults to the proportional or fixed-width font for that system.

size.name: size
size.summary: This attribute specifies the font size as either a numeric or relative value. Numeric values range from 1 to 7 with 1 being the smallest and 3 the default.

bdi.name: bdi
bdi.summary: The `<bdi>` HTML element tells the browser's bidirectional algorithm to treat the text it contains in isolation from its surrounding text. It's particularly useful when a website dynamically inserts some text and doesn't know the directionality of the text being inserted.

bdo.name: bdo
bdo.summary: The `<bdo>` HTML element overrides the current directionality of text, so that the text within is rendered in a different direction.

dir.name: dir
dir.summary: The direction in which text should be rendered in this element's contents. Possible values are.

bgsound.name: bgsound
bgsound.summary: The `<bgsound>` HTML element is deprecated. It sets up a sound file to play in the background while the page is used; use audio instead.

balance.name: balance
balance.summary: This attribute defines a number between -10,000 and +10,000 that determines how the volume will be divided between the speakers.

loop.name: loop
loop.summary: This attribute indicates the number of times a sound is to be played and either has a numeric value or the keyword infinite.

src.name: src
src.summary: This attribute specifies the URL of the sound file to be played, which must be one of the following types: .wav, .au, or .mid.

volume.name: volume
volume.summary: This attribute defines a number between -10,000 and 0 that determines the loudness of a page's background sound.

big.name: big
big.summary: The `<big>` HTML deprecated element renders the enclosed text at a font size one level larger than the surrounding text (`medium` becomes `large`, for example). The size is capped at the browser's maximum permitted font size.

blink.name: blink
blink.summary: The `<blink>` HTML element is a non-standard element which causes the enclosed text to flash slowly.

blockquote.name: blockquote
blockquote.summary: The `<blockquote>` HTML element indicates that the enclosed text is an extended quotation. Usually, this is rendered visually by indentation (see Notes for how to change it). A URL for the source of the quotation may be given using the cite attribute, while a text representation of the source can be given using the cite element.

cite.name: cite
cite.summary: A URL that designates a source document or message for the information quoted. This attribute is intended to point to information explaining the context or the reference for the quote.

body.name: body
body.summary: The `<body>` HTML element represents the content of an HTML document. There can be only one `<body>` element in a document.

alink.name: alink
alink.summary: Color of text for hyperlinks when selected.

background.name: background
background.summary: URI of a image to use as a background.

bottommargin.name: bottommargin
bottommargin.summary: The margin of the bottom of the body.

leftmargin.name: leftmargin
leftmargin.summary: The margin of the left of the body.

link.name: link
link.summary: Color of text for unvisited hypertext links.

onafterprint.name: onafterprint
onafterprint.summary: Function to call after the user has printed the document.

onbeforeprint.name: onbeforeprint
onbeforeprint.summary: Function to call when the user requests printing of the document.

onbeforeunload.name: onbeforeunload
onbeforeunload.summary: Function to call when the document is about to be unloaded.

onblur.name: onblur
onblur.summary: Function to call when the document loses focus.

onerror.name: onerror
onerror.summary: Function to call when the document fails to load properly.

onfocus.name: onfocus
onfocus.summary: Function to call when the document receives focus.

onhashchange.name: onhashchange
onhashchange.summary: Function to call when the fragment identifier part (starting with the hash (`'#'`) character) of the document's current address has changed.

onlanguagechange.name: onlanguagechange
onlanguagechange.summary: Function to call when the preferred languages changed.

onload.name: onload
onload.summary: Function to call when the document has finished loading.

onmessage.name: onmessage
onmessage.summary: Function to call when the document has received a message.

onoffline.name: onoffline
onoffline.summary: Function to call when network communication has failed.

ononline.name: ononline
ononline.summary: Function to call when network communication has been restored.

onpopstate.name: onpopstate
onpopstate.summary: Function to call when the user has navigated session history.

onredo.name: onredo
onredo.summary: Function to call when the user has moved forward in undo transaction history.

onresize.name: onresize
onresize.summary: Function to call when the document has been resized.

onstorage.name: onstorage
onstorage.summary: Function to call when the storage area has changed.

onundo.name: onundo
onundo.summary: Function to call when the user has moved backward in undo transaction history.

onunload.name: onunload
onunload.summary: Function to call when the document is going away.

rightmargin.name: rightmargin
rightmargin.summary: The margin of the right of the body.

topmargin.name: topmargin
topmargin.summary: The margin of the top of the body.

vlink.name: vlink
vlink.summary: Color of text for visited hypertext links.

br.name: br
br.summary:
The `
` HTML element produces a line break in text (carriage-return). It is useful for writing a poem or an address, where the division of lines is significant.

button.name: button
button.summary: The `<button>` HTML element is an interactive element activated by a user with a mouse, keyboard, finger, voice command, or other assistive technology. Once activated, it then performs a programmable action, such as submitting a form or opening a dialog.

autofocus.name: autofocus
autofocus.summary: This Boolean attribute specifies that the button should have input focus when the page loads. Only one element in a document can have this attribute.

autocomplete.name: autocomplete
autocomplete.summary: This attribute on a button is nonstandard and Firefox-specific. Unlike other browsers, Firefox persists the dynamic disabled state of a button across page loads. Setting `autocomplete="off"` on the button disables this feature; see .

disabled.name: disabled
disabled.summary: This Boolean attribute prevents the user from interacting with the button: it cannot be pressed or focused.

form.name: form
form.summary: The form element to associate the button with (its form owner). The value of this attribute must be the `id` of a `<form>` in the same document. (If this attribute is not set, the `<button>` is associated with its ancestor `<form>` element, if any.)

formaction.name: formaction
formaction.summary: The URL that processes the information submitted by the button. Overrides the form attribute of the button's form owner. Does nothing if there is no form owner.

formenctype.name: formenctype
formenctype.summary: If the button is a submit button (it's inside/associated with a `<form>` and doesn't have `type="button"`), specifies how to encode the form data that is submitted

formmethod.name: formmethod
formmethod.summary: If the button is a submit button (it's inside/associated with a `<form>` and doesn't have `type="button"`), this attribute specifies the HTTP method used to submit the form

formnovalidate.name: formnovalidate
formnovalidate.summary: If the button is a submit button, this Boolean attribute specifies that the form is not to be validated when it is submitted. If this attribute is specified, it overrides the form attribute of the button's form owner.

formtarget.name: formtarget
formtarget.summary: If the button is a submit button, this attribute is an author-defined name or standardized, underscore-prefixed keyword indicating where to display the response from submitting the form. This is the `name` of, or keyword for, a browsing context (a tab, window, or iframe). If this attribute is specified, it overrides the target attribute of the button's form owner. The following keywords have special meanings.

name.name: name
name.summary: The name of the button, submitted as a pair with the button's `value` as part of the form data, when that button is used to submit the form.

type.name: type
type.summary: The default behavior of the button. Possible values are.

value.name: value
value.summary: Defines the value associated with the button's `name` when it's submitted with the form data. This value is passed to the server in params when the form is submitted using this button.

canvas.name: canvas
canvas.summary: Use the HTML `<canvas>` element with either the canvas scripting API or the WebGL API to draw graphics and animations.

height.name: height
height.summary: The height of the coordinate space in CSS pixels. Defaults to 150.

moz-opaque.name: moz-opaque
moz-opaque.summary: Lets the canvas know whether or not translucency will be a factor. If the canvas knows there's no translucency, painting performance can be optimized. This is only supported by Mozilla-based browsers; use the standardized {{domxref("HTMLCanvasElement.getContext()", "canvas.getContext('2d', { alpha: false })")}} instead.

width.name: width
width.summary: The width of the coordinate space in CSS pixels. Defaults to 300.

caption.name: caption
caption.summary: The `<caption>` HTML element specifies the caption (or title) of a table.

center.name: center
center.summary: The `<center>` HTML element is a block-level element that displays its block-level or inline contents centered horizontally within its containing element. The container is usually, but isn't required to be, body.

cite.name: cite
cite.summary: The `<cite>` HTML element is used to describe a reference to a cited creative work, and must include the title of that work. The reference may be in an abbreviated form according to context-appropriate conventions related to citation metadata.

code.name: code
code.summary: The `<code>` HTML element displays its contents styled in a fashion intended to indicate that the text is a short fragment of computer code. By default, the content text is displayed using the user agent default monospace font.

col.name: col
col.summary: The `<col>` HTML element defines a column within a table and is used for defining common semantics on all common cells. It is generally found within a colgroup element.

span.name: span
span.summary: This attribute contains a positive integer indicating the number of consecutive columns the `<col>` element spans. If not present, its default value is `1`.

colgroup.name: colgroup
colgroup.summary: The `<colgroup>` HTML element defines a group of columns within a table.

span.name: span
span.summary: This attribute contains a positive integer indicating the number of consecutive columns the `<colgroup>` element spans. If not present, its default value is `1`.

content.name: content
content.summary: The `<content>` HTML element—an obsolete part of the Web Components suite of technologies—was used inside of Shadow DOM as an insertion point, and wasn't meant to be used in ordinary HTML. It has now been replaced by the slot element, which creates a point in the DOM at which a shadow DOM can be inserted.

select.name: select
select.summary: A comma-separated list of selectors. These have the same syntax as CSS selectors. They select the content to insert in place of the `<content>` element.

data.name: data
data.summary: The `<data>` HTML element links a given piece of content with a machine-readable translation. If the content is time- or date-related, the time element must be used.

value.name: value
value.summary: This attribute specifies the machine-readable translation of the content of the element.

datalist.name: datalist
datalist.summary: The `<datalist>` HTML element contains a set of option elements that represent the permissible or recommended options available to choose from within other controls.

dd.name: dd
dd.summary: The `<dd>` HTML element provides the description, definition, or value for the preceding term (dt) in a description list (dl).

nowrap.name: nowrap
nowrap.summary: If the value of this attribute is set to `yes`, the definition text will not wrap. The default value is `no`.

del.name: del
del.summary: The `<del>` HTML element represents a range of text that has been deleted from a document. This can be used when rendering "track changes" or source code diff information, for example. The ins element can be used for the opposite purpose: to indicate text that has been added to the document.

cite.name: cite
cite.summary: A URI for a resource that explains the change (for example, meeting minutes).

datetime.name: datetime
datetime.summary: This attribute indicates the time and date of the change and must be a valid date string with an optional time. If the value cannot be parsed as a date with an optional time string, the element does not have an associated time stamp. For the format of the string without a time, see Date strings. The format of the string if it includes both date and time is covered in Local date and time strings.

details.name: details
details.summary: The `<details>` HTML element creates a disclosure widget in which information is visible only when the widget is toggled into an "open" state. A summary or label must be provided using the summary element.

open.name: open
open.summary: This Boolean attribute indicates whether or not the details — that is, the contents of the `<details>` element — are currently visible. The details are shown when this attribute exists, or hidden when this attribute is absent. By default this attribute is absent which means the details are not visible.

dfn.name: dfn
dfn.summary: The `<dfn>` HTML element is used to indicate the term being defined within the context of a definition phrase or sentence. The p element, the dt/dd pairing, or the section element which is the nearest ancestor of the `<dfn>` is considered to be the definition of the term.

dialog.name: dialog
dialog.summary: The `<dialog>` HTML element represents a dialog box or other interactive component, such as a dismissible alert, inspector, or subwindow.

open.name: open
open.summary: Indicates that the dialog is active and can be interacted with. When the `open` attribute is not set, the dialog shouldn't be shown to the user.

dir.name: dir
dir.summary: The `<dir>` HTML element is used as a container for a directory of files and/or folders, potentially with styles and icons applied by the user agent. Do not use this obsolete element; instead, you should use the ul element for lists, including lists of files.

compact.name: compact
compact.summary: This Boolean attribute hints that the list should be rendered in a compact style. The interpretation of this attribute depends on the user agent and it doesn't work in all browsers.

div.name: div
div.summary: The `<div>` HTML element is the generic container for flow content. It has no effect on the content or layout until styled in some way using CSS (e.g. styling is directly applied to it, or some kind of layout model like Flexbox is applied to its parent element).

dl.name: dl
dl.summary: The `<dl>` HTML element represents a description list. The element encloses a list of groups of terms (specified using the dt element) and descriptions (provided by dd elements). Common uses for this element are to implement a glossary or to display metadata (a list of key-value pairs).

dt.name: dt
dt.summary: The `<dt>` HTML element specifies a term in a description or definition list, and as such must be used inside a dl element. It is usually followed by a dd element; however, multiple `<dt>` elements in a row indicate several terms that are all defined by the immediate next dd element.

em.name: em
em.summary: The `<em>` HTML element marks text that has stress emphasis. The `<em>` element can be nested, with each level of nesting indicating a greater degree of emphasis.

embed.name: embed
embed.summary: The `<embed>` HTML element embeds external content at the specified point in the document. This content is provided by an external application or other source of interactive content such as a browser plug-in.

height.name: height
height.summary: The displayed height of the resource, in CSS pixels. This must be an absolute value; percentages are not allowed.

src.name: src
src.summary: The URL of the resource being embedded.

type.name: type
type.summary: The MIME type to use to select the plug-in to instantiate.

width.name: width
width.summary: The displayed width of the resource, in CSS pixels. This must be an absolute value; percentages are not allowed.

fieldset.name: fieldset
fieldset.summary: The `<fieldset>` HTML element is used to group several controls as well as labels (label) within a web form.

disabled.name: disabled
disabled.summary: If this Boolean attribute is set, all form controls that are descendants of the `<fieldset>`, are disabled, meaning they are not editable and won't be submitted along with the form. They won't receive any browsing events, like mouse clicks or focus-related events. By default browsers display such controls grayed out. Note that form elements inside the legend element won't be disabled.

form.name: form
form.summary: This attribute takes the value of the id attribute of a form element you want the `<fieldset>` to be part of, even if it is not inside the form. Please note that usage of this is confusing — if you want the input elements inside the `<fieldset>` to be associated with the form, you need to use the `form` attribute directly on those elements. You can check which elements are associated with a form via JavaScript, using HTMLFormElement.elements.

name.name: name
name.summary: The name associated with the group.

figcaption.name: figcaption
figcaption.summary: The `<figcaption>` HTML element represents a caption or legend describing the rest of the contents of its parent figure element.

figure.name: figure
figure.summary: The `<figure>` HTML element represents self-contained content, potentially with an optional caption, which is specified using the figcaption element. The figure, its caption, and its contents are referenced as a single unit.

font.name: font
font.summary: The `<font>` HTML element defines the font size, color and face for its content.

color.name: color
color.summary: This attribute sets the text color using either a named color or a color specified in the hexadecimal #RRGGBB format.

face.name: face
face.summary: This attribute contains a comma-separated list of one or more font names. The document text in the default style is rendered in the first font face that the client's browser supports. If no font listed is installed on the local system, the browser typically defaults to the proportional or fixed-width font for that system.

size.name: size
size.summary: This attribute specifies the font size as either a numeric or relative value. Numeric values range from `1` to `7` with `1` being the smallest and `3` the default. It can be defined using a relative value, like `+2` or `-3`, which set it relative to the value of the size attribute of the basefont element, or relative to `3`, the default value, if none does exist.

footer.name: footer
footer.summary: The `<footer>` HTML element represents a footer for its nearest ancestor sectioning content or sectioning root element. A `<footer>` typically contains information about the author of the section, copyright data or links to related documents.

form.name: form
form.summary: The `<form>` HTML element represents a document section containing interactive controls for submitting information.

accept.name: accept
accept.summary: Comma-separated content types the server accepts.

accept-charset.name: accept-charset
accept-charset.summary: Space-separated character encoding the server accepts. The browser uses them in the order in which they are listed. The default value means the same encoding as the page.

autocapitalize.name: autocapitalize
autocapitalize.summary: A nonstandard attribute used by iOS Safari that controls how textual form elements should be automatically capitalized. `autocapitalize` attributes on a form elements override it on `<form>`

autocomplete.name: autocomplete
autocomplete.summary: Indicates whether input elements can by default have their values automatically completed by the browser. `autocomplete` attributes on form elements override it on `<form>`

name.name: name
name.summary: The name of the form. The value must not be the empty string, and must be unique among the `form` elements in the forms collection that it is in, if any.

rel.name: rel
rel.summary: Creates a hyperlink or annotation depending on the value, see the `rel` attribute for details.

frame.name: frame
frame.summary: The `<frame>` HTML element defines a particular area in which another HTML document can be displayed. A frame should be used within a frameset.

src.name: src
src.summary: This attribute specifies the document that will be displayed by the frame.

name.name: name
name.summary: This attribute is used for labeling frames. Without labeling, every link will open in the frame that it's in – the closest parent frame. See the a attribute for more information.

noresize.name: noresize
noresize.summary: This attribute prevents resizing of frames by users.

scrolling.name: scrolling
scrolling.summary: This attribute defines the existence of a scrollbar. If this attribute is not used, the browser adds a scrollbar when necessary. There are two choices: "yes" for forcing a scrollbar even when it is not necessary and "no" for forcing no scrollbar even when it is necessary.

marginheight.name: marginheight
marginheight.summary: This attribute defines the height of the margin between frames.

marginwidth.name: marginwidth
marginwidth.summary: This attribute defines the width of the margin between frames.

frameborder.name: frameborder
frameborder.summary: This attribute allows you to specify a frame's border.

frameset.name: frameset
frameset.summary: The `<frameset>` HTML element is used to contain frame elements.

cols.name: cols
cols.summary: This attribute specifies the number and size of horizontal spaces in a frameset.

rows.name: rows
rows.summary: This attribute specifies the number and size of vertical spaces in a frameset.

head.name: head
head.summary: The `<head>` HTML element contains machine-readable information (metadata) about the document, like its title, scripts, and style sheets.

profile.name: profile
profile.summary: The URIs of one or more metadata profiles, separated by whitespace.

header.name: header
header.summary: The `<header>` HTML element represents introductory content, typically a group of introductory or navigational aids. It may contain some heading elements but also a logo, a search form, an author name, and other elements.

h1.name: h6
h1.summary: The `<h1>` to `<h6>` HTML elements represent six levels of section headings. `<h1>` is the highest section level and `<h6>` is the lowest.

h2.name: h6
h2.summary: The `<h1>` to `<h6>` HTML elements represent six levels of section headings. `<h1>` is the highest section level and `<h6>` is the lowest.

h3.name: h6
h3.summary: The `<h1>` to `<h6>` HTML elements represent six levels of section headings. `<h1>` is the highest section level and `<h6>` is the lowest.

h4.name: h6
h4.summary: The `<h1>` to `<h6>` HTML elements represent six levels of section headings. `<h1>` is the highest section level and `<h6>` is the lowest.

h5.name: h6
h5.summary: The `<h1>` to `<h6>` HTML elements represent six levels of section headings. `<h1>` is the highest section level and `<h6>` is the lowest.

h6.name: h6
h6.summary: The `<h1>` to `<h6>` HTML elements represent six levels of section headings. `<h1>` is the highest section level and `<h6>` is the lowest.

hgroup.name: hgroup
hgroup.summary: Warning: `<hgroup>` should not be used because no assistive technology supports it, and as a result it has a detrimental effect on assistance for headings placed within it. > > For more information see the Usage notes below.

hr.name: hr
hr.summary: The `<hr>` HTML element represents a thematic break between paragraph-level elements: for example, a change of scene in a story, or a shift of topic within a section.

align.name: align
align.summary: Sets the alignment of the rule on the page. If no value is specified, the default value is `left`.

color.name: color
color.summary: Sets the color of the rule through color name or hexadecimal value.

noshade.name: noshade
noshade.summary: Sets the rule to have no shading.

size.name: size
size.summary: Sets the height, in pixels, of the rule.

width.name: width
width.summary: Sets the length of the rule on the page through a pixel or percentage value.

html.name: html
html.summary: The `<html>` HTML element represents the root (top-level element) of an HTML document, so it is also referred to as the root element. All other elements must be descendants of this element.

manifest.name: manifest
manifest.summary: Specifies the URI of a resource manifest indicating resources that should be cached locally.

version.name: version
version.summary: Specifies the version of the HTML Doctype that governs the current document. This attribute is not needed, because it is redundant with the version information in the document type declaration.

xmlns.name: xmlns
xmlns.summary: Specifies the XML Namespace of the document. Default value is `"http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"`. This is required in documents parsed with XML parser, and optional in text/html documents.

i.name: i
i.summary: The `<i>` HTML element represents a range of text that is set off from the normal text for some reason, such as idiomatic text, technical terms, taxonomical designations, among others. Historically, these have been presented using italicized type, which is the original source of the `<i>` naming of this element.

iframe.name: iframe
iframe.summary: The `<iframe>` HTML element represents a nested browsing context, embedding another HTML page into the current one.

allow.name: allow
allow.summary: Specifies a feature policy for the `<iframe>`. The policy defines what features are available to the `<iframe>` based on the origin of the request (e.g. access to the microphone, camera, battery, web-share API, etc.).

allowfullscreen.name: allowfullscreen
allowfullscreen.summary: Set to `true` if the `<iframe>` can activate fullscreen mode by calling the Element.requestFullscreen method.

allowpaymentrequest.name: allowpaymentrequest
allowpaymentrequest.summary: Set to `true` if a cross-origin `<iframe>` should be allowed to invoke the Payment Request API.

csp.name: csp
csp.summary: A Content Security Policy enforced for the embedded resource. See HTMLIFrameElement.csp for details.

fetchpriority.name: fetchpriority
fetchpriority.summary: Provides a hint of the relative priority to use when fetching the iframe document

height.name: height
height.summary: The height of the frame in CSS pixels. Default is `150`.

loading.name: loading
loading.summary: Indicates how the browser should load the iframe.

name.name: name
name.summary: A targetable name for the embedded browsing context. This can be used in the `target` attribute of the a, form, or base elements; the `formtarget` attribute of the input or button elements; or the `windowName` parameter in the window.open() method.

referrerpolicy.name: referrerpolicy
referrerpolicy.summary: Indicates which referrer to send when fetching the frame's resource.

sandbox.name: sandbox
sandbox.summary: Applies extra restrictions to the content in the frame. The value of the attribute can either be empty to apply all restrictions, or space-separated tokens to lift particular restrictions.

src.name: src
src.summary: The URL of the page to embed. Use a value of `about:blank` to embed an empty page that conforms to the same-origin policy. Also note that programmatically removing an `<iframe>`'s src attribute (e.g. via Element.removeAttribute()) causes `about:blank` to be loaded in the frame in Firefox (from version 65), Chromium-based browsers, and Safari/iOS.

srcdoc.name: srcdoc
srcdoc.summary: Inline HTML to embed, overriding the `src` attribute. If a browser does not support the `srcdoc` attribute, it will fall back to the URL in the `src` attribute.

width.name: width
width.summary: The width of the frame in CSS pixels. Default is `300`.

image.name: image
image.summary: The `<image>` HTML element is an ancient and poorly supported precursor to the img element. It should not be used.

img.name: img
img.summary: The `` HTML element embeds an image into the document.

alt.name: alt
alt.summary: Defines an alternative text description of the image.

crossorigin.name: crossorigin
crossorigin.summary: Indicates if the fetching of the image must be done using a CORS request. Image data from a CORS-enabled image returned from a CORS request can be reused in the canvas element without being marked "tainted".

decoding.name: decoding
decoding.summary: Provides an image decoding hint to the browser

fetchpriority.name: fetchpriority
fetchpriority.summary: Provides a hint of the relative priority to use when fetching the image

height.name: height
height.summary: The intrinsic height of the image, in pixels. Must be an integer without a unit.

ismap.name: ismap
ismap.summary: This Boolean attribute indicates that the image is part of a server-side map. If so, the coordinates where the user clicked on the image are sent to the server.

loading.name: loading
loading.summary: Indicates how the browser should load the image.

referrerpolicy.name: referrerpolicy
referrerpolicy.summary: A string indicating which referrer to use when fetching the resource.

sizes.name: sizes
sizes.summary: One or more strings separated by commas, indicating a set of source sizes. Each source size consists of.

src.name: src
src.summary: The image URL. Mandatory for the `` element. On Browser supporting `srcset`, `src` is treated like a candidate image with a pixel density descriptor `1x`, unless an image with this pixel density descriptor is already defined in `srcset`, or unless `srcset` contains `w` descriptors.

srcset.name: srcset
srcset.summary: One or more strings separated by commas, indicating possible image sources for the user agent to use. Each string is composed of.

width.name: width
width.summary: The intrinsic width of the image in pixels. Must be an integer without a unit.

usemap.name: usemap
usemap.summary: The partial URL (starting with `#`) of an image map associated with the element.

input.name: input
input.summary: The `<input>` HTML element is used to create interactive controls for web-based forms in order to accept data from the user; a wide variety of types of input data and control widgets are available, depending on the device and user agent. The `<input>` element is one of the most powerful and complex in all of HTML due to the sheer number of combinations of input types and attributes.

ins.name: ins
ins.summary: The `<ins>` HTML element represents a range of text that has been added to a document. You can use the del element to similarly represent a range of text that has been deleted from the document.

cite.name: cite
cite.summary: This attribute defines the URI of a resource that explains the change, such as a link to meeting minutes or a ticket in a troubleshooting system.

datetime.name: datetime
datetime.summary: This attribute indicates the time and date of the change and must be a valid date with an optional time string. If the value cannot be parsed as a date with an optional time string, the element does not have an associated time stamp. For the format of the string without a time, see Format of a valid date string. The format of the string if it includes both date and time is covered in Format of a valid local date and time string.

kbd.name: kbd
kbd.summary: The `<kbd>` HTML element represents a span of inline text denoting textual user input from a keyboard, voice input, or any other text entry device. By convention, the user agent defaults to rendering the contents of a `<kbd>` element using its default monospace font, although this is not mandated by the HTML standard.

keygen.name: keygen
keygen.summary: The `<keygen>` HTML element exists to facilitate generation of key material, and submission of the public key as part of an HTML form. This mechanism is designed for use with Web-based certificate management systems. It is expected that the `<keygen>` element will be used in an HTML form along with other information needed to construct a certificate request, and that the result of the process will be a signed certificate.

autofocus.name: autofocus
autofocus.summary: This Boolean attribute lets you specify that the control should have input focus when the page loads, unless the user overrides it, for example by typing in a different control. Only one form element in a document can have the `autofocus` attribute, which is a Boolean.

challenge.name: challenge
challenge.summary: A challenge string that is submitted along with the public key. Defaults to an empty string if not specified.

disabled.name: disabled
disabled.summary: This Boolean attribute indicates that the form control is not available for interaction.

form.name: form
form.summary: The form element that this element is associated with (its form owner). The value of the attribute must be an `id` of a form element in the same document. If this attribute is not specified, this element must be a descendant of a form element. This attribute enables you to place `<keygen>` elements anywhere within a document, not just as descendants of their form elements.

keytype.name: keytype
keytype.summary: The type of key generated. The default value is `RSA`.

name.name: name
name.summary: The name of the control, which is submitted with the form data.

label.name: label
label.summary: The `<label>` HTML element represents a caption for an item in a user interface.

for.name: for
for.summary: The value of the `for` attribute must be a single id for a labelable form-related element in the same document as the `<label>` element. So, any given `label` element can be associated with only one form control.

legend.name: legend
legend.summary: The `<legend>` HTML element represents a caption for the content of its parent fieldset.

li.name: li
li.summary: The `<li>` HTML element is used to represent an item in a list. It must be contained in a parent element: an ordered list (ol), an unordered list (ul), or a menu (menu). In menus and unordered lists, list items are usually displayed using bullet points. In ordered lists, they are usually displayed with an ascending counter on the left, such as a number or letter.

value.name: value
value.summary: This integer attribute indicates the current ordinal value of the list item as defined by the ol element. The only allowed value for this attribute is a number, even if the list is displayed with Roman numerals or letters. List items that follow this one continue numbering from the value set. The value attribute has no meaning for unordered lists (ul) or for menus (menu).

type.name: type
type.summary: This character attribute indicates the numbering type.

link.name: link
link.summary: The `<link>` HTML element specifies relationships between the current document and an external resource. This element is most commonly used to link to CSS, but is also used to establish site icons (both "favicon" style icons and icons for the home screen and apps on mobile devices) among other things.

as.name: as
as.summary: This attribute is only used when `rel="preload"` or `rel="prefetch"` has been set on the `<link>` element.

crossorigin.name: crossorigin
crossorigin.summary: This enumerated attribute indicates whether CORS must be used when fetching the resource.

disabled.name: disabled
disabled.summary: For `rel="stylesheet"` only, the `disabled` Boolean attribute indicates whether or not the described stylesheet should be loaded and applied to the document.

fetchpriority.name: fetchpriority
fetchpriority.summary: Provides a hint of the relative priority to use when fetching a preloaded resource

href.name: href
href.summary: This attribute specifies the URL of the linked resource. A URL can be absolute or relative.

hreflang.name: hreflang
hreflang.summary: This attribute indicates the language of the linked resource.

imagesizes.name: imagesizes
imagesizes.summary: For `rel="preload"` and `as="image"` only, the `imagesizes` attribute is a sizes attribute that indicates to preload the appropriate resource used by an `img` element with corresponding values for its `srcset` and `sizes` attributes.

imagesrcset.name: imagesrcset
imagesrcset.summary: For `rel="preload"` and `as="image"` only, the `imagesrcset` attribute is a sourceset attribute that indicates to preload the appropriate resource used by an `img` element with corresponding values for its `srcset` and `sizes` attributes.

integrity.name: integrity
integrity.summary: Contains inline metadata — a base64-encoded cryptographic hash of the resource (file) you're telling the browser to fetch.

media.name: media
media.summary: This attribute specifies the media that the linked resource applies to. Its value must be a media type / media query.

prefetch.name: prefetch
prefetch.summary: Identifies a resource that might be required by the next navigation and that the user agent should retrieve it.

referrerpolicy.name: referrerpolicy
referrerpolicy.summary: A string indicating which referrer to use when fetching the resource.

rel.name: rel
rel.summary: This attribute names a relationship of the linked document to the current document. The attribute must be a space-separated list of link type values.

sizes.name: sizes
sizes.summary: This attribute defines the sizes of the icons for visual media contained in the resource.

title.name: title
title.summary: The `title` attribute has special semantics on the `<link>` element.

type.name: type
type.summary: This attribute is used to define the type of the content linked to.

main.name: main
main.summary: The `<main>` HTML element represents the dominant content of the body of a document. The main content area consists of content that is directly related to or expands upon the central topic of a document, or the central functionality of an application.

map.name: map
map.summary: The `<map>` HTML element is used with area elements to define an image map (a clickable link area).

name.name: name
name.summary: The `name` attribute gives the map a name so that it can be referenced. The attribute must be present and must have a non-empty value with no space characters. The value of the `name` attribute must not be equal to the value of the `name` attribute of another `<map>` element in the same document. If the id attribute is also specified, both attributes must have the same value.

mark.name: mark
mark.summary: The `<mark>` HTML element represents text which is marked or highlighted for reference or notation purposes, due to the marked passage's relevance or importance in the enclosing context.

marquee.name: marquee
marquee.summary: The `<marquee>` HTML element is used to insert a scrolling area of text. You can control what happens when the text reaches the edges of its content area using its attributes.

behavior.name: behavior
behavior.summary: Sets how the text is scrolled within the marquee. Possible values are `scroll`, `slide` and `alternate`. If no value is specified, the default value is `scroll`.

bgcolor.name: bgcolor
bgcolor.summary: Sets the background color through color name or hexadecimal value.

direction.name: direction
direction.summary: Sets the direction of the scrolling within the marquee. Possible values are `left`, `right`, `up` and `down`. If no value is specified, the default value is `left`.

height.name: height
height.summary: Sets the height in pixels or percentage value.

loop.name: loop
loop.summary: Sets the number of times the marquee will scroll. If no value is specified, the default value is −1, which means the marquee will scroll continuously.

scrollamount.name: scrollamount
scrollamount.summary: Sets the amount of scrolling at each interval in pixels. The default value is 6.

scrolldelay.name: scrolldelay
scrolldelay.summary: Sets the interval between each scroll movement in milliseconds. The default value is 85. Note that any value smaller than 60 is ignored and the value 60 is used instead, unless`truespeed`is specified.

truespeed.name: truespeed
truespeed.summary: By default,`scrolldelay`values lower than 60 are ignored. If`truespeed`is present, those values are not ignored.

vspace.name: vspace
vspace.summary: Sets the vertical margin in pixels or percentage value.

width.name: width
width.summary: Sets the width in pixels or percentage value.

menu.name: menu
menu.summary: The `<menu>` HTML element is a semantic alternative to ul. It represents an unordered list of items (represented by li elements), each of which represents a link or other command that the user can activate.

menuitem.name: menuitem
menuitem.summary: The `<menuitem>` HTML element represents a command that a user is able to invoke through a popup menu. This includes context menus, as well as menus that might be attached to a menu button.

checked.name: checked
checked.summary: Boolean attribute which indicates whether the command is selected. May only be used when the `type` attribute is `checkbox` or `radio`.

command.name: command
command.summary: Specifies the ID of a separate element, indicating a command to be invoked indirectly. May not be used within a menu item that also includes the attributes `checked`, `disabled`, `icon`, `label`, `radiogroup` or `type`.

default.name: default
default.summary: This Boolean attribute indicates use of the same command as the menu's subject element (such as a `button` or `input`).

disabled.name: disabled
disabled.summary: Boolean attribute which indicates that the command is not available in the current state. Note that `disabled` is distinct from `hidden`; the `disabled` attribute is appropriate in any context where a change in circumstances might render the command relevant.

icon.name: icon
icon.summary: Image URL, used to provide a picture to represent the command.

label.name: label
label.summary: The name of the command as shown to the user. Required when a `command` attribute is not present.

radiogroup.name: radiogroup
radiogroup.summary: This attribute specifies the name of a group of commands to be toggled as radio buttons when selected. May only be used where the `type` attribute is `radio`.

type.name: type
type.summary: This attribute indicates the kind of command, and can be one of three values.

meta.name: meta
meta.summary: The `<meta>` HTML element represents metadata that cannot be represented by other HTML meta-related elements, like base, link, script, style or title.

charset.name: charset
charset.summary: This attribute declares the document's character encoding. If the attribute is present, its value must be an ASCII case-insensitive match for the string "`utf-8`", because UTF-8 is the only valid encoding for HTML5 documents. `<meta>` elements which declare a character encoding must be located entirely within the first 1024 bytes of the document.

content.name: content
content.summary: This attribute contains the value for the http-equiv or name attribute, depending on which is used.

http-equiv.name: http-equiv
http-equiv.summary: Defines a pragma directive. The attribute is named `http-equiv(alent)` because all the allowed values are names of particular HTTP headers.

meter.name: meter
meter.summary: The `<meter>` HTML element represents either a scalar value within a known range or a fractional value.

value.name: value
value.summary: The current numeric value. This must be between the minimum and maximum values (`min` attribute and `max` attribute) if they are specified. If unspecified or malformed, the value is `0`. If specified, but not within the range given by the `min` attribute and `max` attribute, the value is equal to the nearest end of the range.

min.name: min
min.summary: The lower numeric bound of the measured range. This must be less than the maximum value (`max` attribute), if specified. If unspecified, the minimum value is `0`.

max.name: max
max.summary: The upper numeric bound of the measured range. This must be greater than the minimum value (`min` attribute), if specified. If unspecified, the maximum value is `1`.

low.name: low
low.summary: The upper numeric bound of the low end of the measured range. This must be greater than the minimum value (`min` attribute), and it also must be less than the high value and maximum value (`high` attribute and `max` attribute, respectively), if any are specified. If unspecified, or if less than the minimum value, the `low` value is equal to the minimum value.

high.name: high
high.summary: The lower numeric bound of the high end of the measured range. This must be less than the maximum value (`max` attribute), and it also must be greater than the low value and minimum value (`low` attribute and `min` attribute, respectively), if any are specified. If unspecified, or if greater than the maximum value, the `high` value is equal to the maximum value.

optimum.name: optimum
optimum.summary: This attribute indicates the optimal numeric value. It must be within the range (as defined by the `min` attribute and `max` attribute). When used with the `low` attribute and `high` attribute, it gives an indication where along the range is considered preferable. For example, if it is between the `min` attribute and the `low` attribute, then the lower range is considered preferred. The browser may color the meter's bar differently depending on whether the value is less than or equal to the optimum value.

nav.name: nav
nav.summary: The `<nav>` HTML element represents a section of a page whose purpose is to provide navigation links, either within the current document or to other documents. Common examples of navigation sections are menus, tables of contents, and indexes.

nobr.name: nobr
nobr.summary: The `<nobr>` HTML element prevents the text it contains from automatically wrapping across multiple lines, potentially resulting in the user having to scroll horizontally to see the entire width of the text.

noembed.name: noembed
noembed.summary: The `<noembed>` HTML element is an obsolete, non-standard way to provide alternative, or "fallback", content for browsers that do not support the embed element or do not support the type of embedded content an author wishes to use. This element was deprecated in HTML 4.01 and above in favor of placing fallback content between the opening and closing tags of an object element.

noframes.name: noframes
noframes.summary: The `<noframes>` HTML element provides content to be presented in browsers that don't support (or have disabled support for) the frame element. Although most commonly-used browsers support frames, there are exceptions, including certain special-use browsers including some mobile browsers, as well as text-mode browsers.

noscript.name: noscript
noscript.summary: The `<noscript>` HTML element defines a section of HTML to be inserted if a script type on the page is unsupported or if scripting is currently turned off in the browser.

object.name: object
object.summary: The `<object>` HTML element represents an external resource, which can be treated as an image, a nested browsing context, or a resource to be handled by a plugin.

archive.name: archive
archive.summary: A space-separated list of URIs for archives of resources for the object.

border.name: border
border.summary: The width of a border around the control, in pixels.

classid.name: classid
classid.summary: The URI of the object's implementation. It can be used together with, or in place of, the data attribute.

codebase.name: codebase
codebase.summary: The base path used to resolve relative URIs specified by classid, data, or archive. If not specified, the default is the base URI of the current document.

codetype.name: codetype
codetype.summary: The content type of the data specified by classid.

data.name: data
data.summary: The address of the resource as a valid URL. At least one of data and type must be defined.

declare.name: declare
declare.summary: The presence of this Boolean attribute makes this element a declaration only. The object must be instantiated by a subsequent `<object>` element. In HTML5, repeat the <object> element completely each time that the resource is reused.

form.name: form
form.summary: The form element, if any, that the object element is associated with (its form owner). The value of the attribute must be an ID of a form element in the same document.

height.name: height
height.summary: The height of the displayed resource, in CSS pixels. -- (Absolute values only. NO percentages)

name.name: name
name.summary: The name of valid browsing context (HTML5), or the name of the control (HTML 4).

standby.name: standby
standby.summary: A message that the browser can show while loading the object's implementation and data.

type.name: type
type.summary: The content type of the resource specified by data. At least one of data and type must be defined.

usemap.name: usemap
usemap.summary: A hash-name reference to a map element; that is a '#' followed by the value of a name of a map element.

width.name: width
width.summary: The width of the display resource, in CSS pixels. -- (Absolute values only. NO percentages)

ol.name: ol
ol.summary: The `<ol>` HTML element represents an ordered list of items — typically rendered as a numbered list.

reversed.name: reversed
reversed.summary: This Boolean attribute specifies that the list's items are in reverse order. Items will be numbered from high to low.

start.name: start
start.summary: An integer to start counting from for the list items. Always an Arabic numeral (1, 2, 3, etc.), even when the numbering `type` is letters or Roman numerals. For example, to start numbering elements from the letter "d" or the Roman numeral "iv," use `start="4"`.

optgroup.name: optgroup
optgroup.summary: The `<optgroup>` HTML element creates a grouping of options within a select element.

disabled.name: disabled
disabled.summary: If this Boolean attribute is set, none of the items in this option group is selectable. Often browsers grey out such control and it won't receive any browsing events, like mouse clicks or focus-related ones.

label.name: label
label.summary: The name of the group of options, which the browser can use when labeling the options in the user interface. This attribute is mandatory if this element is used.

option.name: option
option.summary: The `<option>` HTML element is used to define an item contained in a select, an optgroup, or a datalist element. As such, `<option>` can represent menu items in popups and other lists of items in an HTML document.

disabled.name: disabled
disabled.summary: If this Boolean attribute is set, this option is not checkable. Often browsers grey out such control and it won't receive any browsing event, like mouse clicks or focus-related ones. If this attribute is not set, the element can still be disabled if one of its ancestors is a disabled optgroup element.

label.name: label
label.summary: This attribute is text for the label indicating the meaning of the option. If the `label` attribute isn't defined, its value is that of the element text content.

selected.name: selected
selected.summary: If present, this Boolean attribute indicates that the option is initially selected. If the `<option>` element is the descendant of a select element whose multiple attribute is not set, only one single `<option>` of this select element may have the `selected` attribute.

value.name: value
value.summary: The content of this attribute represents the value to be submitted with the form, should this option be selected. If this attribute is omitted, the value is taken from the text content of the option element.

output.name: output
output.summary: The `<output>` HTML element is a container element into which a site or app can inject the results of a calculation or the outcome of a user action.

for.name: for
for.summary: A space-separated list of other elements' ids, indicating that those elements contributed input values to (or otherwise affected) the calculation.

form.name: form
form.summary: The form element to associate the output with (its form owner). The value of this attribute must be the id of a `<form>` in the same document. (If this attribute is not set, the `<output>` is associated with its ancestor `<form>` element, if any.)

name.name: name
name.summary: The element's name. Used in the HTMLFormElement.elements API.

p.name: p
p.summary:
The `

` HTML element represents a paragraph. Paragraphs are usually represented in visual media as blocks of text separated from adjacent blocks by blank lines and/or first-line indentation, but HTML paragraphs can be any structural grouping of related content, such as images or form fields.

param.name: param
param.summary: The `<param>` HTML element defines parameters for an object element.

value.name: value
value.summary: Specifies the value of the parameter.

type.name: type
type.summary: Only used if the `valuetype` is set to `ref`. Specifies the MIME type of values found at the URI specified by value.

valuetype.name: valuetype
valuetype.summary: Specifies the type of the `value` attribute. Possible values are.

picture.name: picture
picture.summary: The `<picture>` HTML element contains zero or more source elements and one img element to offer alternative versions of an image for different display/device scenarios.

plaintext.name: plaintext
plaintext.summary: The `<plaintext>` HTML element renders everything following the start tag as raw text, ignoring any following HTML. There is no closing tag, since everything after it is considered raw text.

portal.name: portal
portal.summary: The `<portal>` HTML element enables the embedding of another HTML page into the current one for the purposes of allowing smoother navigation into new pages.

referrerpolicy.name: referrerpolicy
referrerpolicy.summary: Sets the referrer policy to use when requesting the page at the URL given as the value of the `src` attribute.

src.name: src
src.summary: The URL of the page to embed.

pre.name: pre
pre.summary: The `<pre>` HTML element represents preformatted text which is to be presented exactly as written in the HTML file. The text is typically rendered using a non-proportional, or monospaced, font. Whitespace inside this element is displayed as written.

cols.name: cols
cols.summary: Contains the preferred count of characters that a line should have. It was a non-standard synonym of width. To achieve such an effect, use CSS width instead.

width.name: width
width.summary: Contains the preferred count of characters that a line should have. Though technically still implemented, this attribute has no visual effect; to achieve such an effect, use CSS width instead.

wrap.name: wrap
wrap.summary: Is a hint indicating how the overflow must happen. In modern browser this hint is ignored and no visual effect results in its present; to achieve such an effect, use CSS white-space instead.

progress.name: progress
progress.summary: The `<progress>` HTML element displays an indicator showing the completion progress of a task, typically displayed as a progress bar.

q.name: q
q.summary: The `<q>` HTML element indicates that the enclosed text is a short inline quotation. Most modern browsers implement this by surrounding the text in quotation marks. This element is intended for short quotations that don't require paragraph breaks; for long quotations use the blockquote element.

cite.name: cite
cite.summary: The value of this attribute is a URL that designates a source document or message for the information quoted. This attribute is intended to point to information explaining the context or the reference for the quote.

rb.name: rb
rb.summary: The `<rb>` HTML element is used to delimit the base text component of a ruby annotation, i.e. the text that is being annotated. One `<rb>` element should wrap each separate atomic segment of the base text.

rp.name: rp
rp.summary: The `<rp>` HTML element is used to provide fall-back parentheses for browsers that do not support display of ruby annotations using the ruby element. One `<rp>` element should enclose each of the opening and closing parentheses that wrap the rt element that contains the annotation's text.

rt.name: rt
rt.summary: The `<rt>` HTML element specifies the ruby text component of a ruby annotation, which is used to provide pronunciation, translation, or transliteration information for East Asian typography. The `<rt>` element must always be contained within a ruby element.

rtc.name: rtc
rtc.summary: The `<rtc>` HTML element embraces semantic annotations of characters presented in a ruby of rb elements used inside of ruby element. rb elements can have both pronunciation (rt) and semantic (rtc) annotations.

ruby.name: ruby
ruby.summary: The `<ruby>` HTML element represents small annotations that are rendered above, below, or next to base text, usually used for showing the pronunciation of East Asian characters. It can also be used for annotating other kinds of text, but this usage is less common.

s.name: s
s.summary: The `<s>` HTML element renders text with a strikethrough, or a line through it. Use the `<s>` element to represent things that are no longer relevant or no longer accurate. However, `<s>` is not appropriate when indicating document edits; for that, use the del and ins elements, as appropriate.

samp.name: samp
samp.summary: The `<samp>` HTML element is used to enclose inline text which represents sample (or quoted) output from a computer program. Its contents are typically rendered using the browser's default monospaced font (such as wikipedia or Lucida Console).

script.name: script
script.summary: The `<script>` HTML element is used to embed executable code or data; this is typically used to embed or refer to JavaScript code. The `<script>` element can also be used with other languages, such as WebGL's GLSL shader programming language and JSON.

async.name: async
async.summary: For classic scripts, if the `async` attribute is present, then the classic script will be fetched in parallel to parsing and evaluated as soon as it is available.

crossorigin.name: crossorigin
crossorigin.summary: Normal `script` elements pass minimal information to the  for scripts which do not pass the standard CORS checks. To allow error logging for sites which use a separate domain for static media, use this attribute. See CORS settings attributes for a more descriptive explanation of its valid arguments.

defer.name: defer
defer.summary: This Boolean attribute is set to indicate to a browser that the script is meant to be executed after the document has been parsed, but before firing Document/DOMContentLoaded_event.

fetchpriority.name: fetchpriority
fetchpriority.summary: Provides a hint of the relative priority to use when fetching an external script

integrity.name: integrity
integrity.summary: This attribute contains inline metadata that a user agent can use to verify that a fetched resource has been delivered free of unexpected manipulation. See Subresource Integrity.

nomodule.name: nomodule
nomodule.summary: This Boolean attribute is set to indicate that the script should not be executed in browsers that support ES2015 modules — in effect, this can be used to serve fallback scripts to older browsers that do not support modular JavaScript code.

nonce.name: nonce
nonce.summary: A cryptographic nonce (number used once) to allow scripts in a script-src Content-Security-Policy. The server must generate a unique nonce value each time it transmits a policy. It is critical to provide a nonce that cannot be guessed as bypassing a resource's policy is otherwise trivial.

referrerpolicy.name: referrerpolicy
referrerpolicy.summary: Indicates which referrer to send when fetching the script, or resources fetched by the script.

src.name: src
src.summary: This attribute specifies the URI of an external script; this can be used as an alternative to embedding a script directly within a document.

type.name: type
type.summary: This attribute indicates the type of script represented. The value of this attribute will be in one of the following categories.

section.name: section
section.summary: The `<section>` HTML element represents a generic standalone section of a document, which doesn't have a more specific semantic element to represent it. Sections should always have a heading, with very few exceptions.

select.name: select
select.summary: The `<select>` HTML element represents a control that provides a menu of options.

autocomplete.name: autocomplete
autocomplete.summary: A string providing a hint for a user agent autocomplete feature. See The HTML autocomplete attribute for a complete list of values and details on how to use autocomplete.

autofocus.name: autofocus
autofocus.summary: This Boolean attribute lets you specify that a form control should have input focus when the page loads. Only one form element in a document can have the `autofocus` attribute.

disabled.name: disabled
disabled.summary: This Boolean attribute indicates that the user cannot interact with the control. If this attribute is not specified, the control inherits its setting from the containing element, for example fieldset; if there is no containing element with the `disabled` attribute set, then the control is enabled.

form.name: form
form.summary: The form element to associate the `<select>` with (its form owner). The value of this attribute must be the id of a `<form>` in the same document. (If this attribute is not set, the `<select>` is associated with its ancestor `<form>` element, if any.)

multiple.name: multiple
multiple.summary: This Boolean attribute indicates that multiple options can be selected in the list. If it is not specified, then only one option can be selected at a time. When `multiple` is specified, most browsers will show a scrolling list box instead of a single line dropdown.

name.name: name
name.summary: This attribute is used to specify the name of the control.

required.name: required
required.summary: A Boolean attribute indicating that an option with a non-empty string value must be selected.

size.name: size
size.summary: If the control is presented as a scrolling list box (e.g. when `multiple` is specified), this attribute represents the number of rows in the list that should be visible at one time. Browsers are not required to present a select element as a scrolled list box. The default value is `0`.

shadow.name: shadow
shadow.summary: The `<shadow>` HTML element—an obsolete part of the Web Components technology suite—was intended to be used as a shadow DOM insertion point. You might have used it if you have created multiple shadow roots under a shadow host. It is not useful in ordinary HTML.

slot.name: slot
slot.summary: The `<slot>` HTML element—part of the Web Components technology suite—is a placeholder inside a web component that you can fill with your own markup, which lets you create separate DOM trees and present them together.

small.name: small
small.summary: The `<small>` HTML element represents side-comments and small print, like copyright and legal text, independent of its styled presentation. By default, it renders text within it one font-size smaller, such as from `small` to `x-small`.

source.name: source
source.summary: The `<source>` HTML element specifies multiple media resources for the picture, the audio element, or the video element. It is an empty element, meaning that it has no content and does not have a closing tag. It is commonly used to offer the same media content in multiple file formats in order to provide compatibility with a broad range of browsers given their differing support for image file formats and media file formats.

type.name: type
type.summary: The MIME media type of the resource, optionally with a `codecs` parameter.

src.name: src
src.summary: Required if the `source` element’s parent is an audio and video element, but not allowed if the `source` element’s parent is a picture element.

srcset.name: srcset
srcset.summary: Required if the `source` element’s parent is a picture element, but not allowed if the `source` element’s parent is an audio or video element.

sizes.name: sizes
sizes.summary: Allowed if the `source` element’s parent is a picture element, but not allowed if the `source` element’s parent is an audio or video element.

media.name: media
media.summary: Allowed if the `source` element’s parent is a picture element, but not allowed if the `source` element’s parent is an audio or video element.

height.name: height
height.summary: Allowed if the `source` element’s parent is a picture element, but not allowed if the `source` element’s parent is an audio or video element.

width.name: width
width.summary: Allowed if the `source` element’s parent is a picture element, but not allowed if the `source` element’s parent is an audio or video element.

spacer.name: spacer
spacer.summary: The `<spacer>` HTML element is an obsolete HTML element which allowed insertion of empty spaces on pages. It was devised by Netscape to accomplish the same effect as a single-pixel layout image, which was something web designers used to use to add white spaces to web pages without actually using an image. However, `<spacer>` no longer supported by any major browser and the same effects can now be achieved using simple CSS.

span.name: span
span.summary: The `<span>` HTML element is a generic inline container for phrasing content, which does not inherently represent anything. It can be used to group elements for styling purposes (using the class or id attributes), or because they share attribute values, such as lang. It should be used only when no other semantic element is appropriate. `<span>` is very much like a div element, but div is a block-level element whereas a `<span>` is an inline element.

strike.name: strike
strike.summary: The `<strike>` HTML element places a strikethrough (horizontal line) over text.

strong.name: strong
strong.summary: The `<strong>` HTML element indicates that its contents have strong importance, seriousness, or urgency. Browsers typically render the contents in bold type.

style.name: style
style.summary: The `<style>` HTML element contains style information for a document, or part of a document. It contains CSS, which is applied to the contents of the document containing the `<style>` element.

media.name: media
media.summary: This attribute defines which media the style should be applied to. Its value is a media query, which defaults to `all` if the attribute is missing.

nonce.name: nonce
nonce.summary: A cryptographic nonce (number used once) used to allow inline styles in a style-src Content-Security-Policy. The server must generate a unique nonce value each time it transmits a policy. It is critical to provide a nonce that cannot be guessed as bypassing a resource's policy is otherwise trivial.

title.name: title
title.summary: This attribute specifies alternative style sheet sets.

sub.name: sub
sub.summary: The `<sub>` HTML element specifies inline text which should be displayed as subscript for solely typographical reasons. Subscripts are typically rendered with a lowered baseline using smaller text.

summary.name: summary
summary.summary: The `<summary>` HTML element specifies a summary, caption, or legend for a details element's disclosure box. Clicking the `<summary>` element toggles the state of the parent `<details>` element open and closed.

sup.name: sup
sup.summary: The `<sup>` HTML element specifies inline text which is to be displayed as superscript for solely typographical reasons. Superscripts are usually rendered with a raised baseline using smaller text.

table.name: table
table.summary: The `<table>` HTML element represents tabular data — that is, information presented in a two-dimensional table comprised of rows and columns of cells containing data.

tbody.name: tbody
